What are parametric curves?

So far we have primarily studied functions which are a function of one variable, whether explicitly or implicitly. All of the functions we have met so far could be expressed in the form \(y = f(x)\), that is, the variable \(y\) is a function of the variable of \(x\) and we have expressed these functions graphically on the usual \(x-y\) plane, which is called the Cartesian plane. This is one of the most simple ways to represent a given function. However, this process can be generalised fairly intuitively. One way we could do this is to consider a function with multiple inputs. For example the function \(x^2 + y^2 = 9\) (which is the equation of a circle centre at the origin and radius three) could be denoted as \(z = f(x,y)\) because it is a function with two independent variables \(x\) and \(y\). You can see that we could define functions in a similar manner for \(n\) independent variables, for example \(y = f(x_1, \dots, x_n) = x_1 + \cdots + x_n\) is a function with \(n\) independent variables. In this section we will look at a similar, but different way we can represent functions, these are parametric functions.


A parametric curve is a curve drawn by specifying each point in the plane \((x,y)\) that lies on the curve in terms of a third variable, or parameter, \(t\).  So the points on the curve are all those points of the form \( (f(t),  g(t))\) for some functions \(x=f(t)\) and \(y = g(t)\).  This is useful when the curve we want to sketch is not the graph of a function \(y = f(x)\). The following example illustrates why we are interested in these curves this week.


Example

The points on the unit circle centred at the origin are all those points \((x,y)\) such that \(x^2 + y^2 = 1\).  So we can define the circle via that equation, or we can define it parametrically.  Recall from week five that we can define the values \(\cos(\theta)\) and \(\sin(\theta)\) are the \(x\)- and \(y\)- coordinates of points on the unit circle which are an angle \(\theta\) from the positive \(x\)-axis.  So \(f(\theta) = \cos(\theta)\) and \(g(\theta) = \sin(\theta)\) is a parametric representation of the circle: as \(\theta\) varies, the point \((\cos(\theta), \sin(\theta))\) runs around the circle.



This corresponds with the fact that \(\sin^2(\theta) + \cos^2(\theta) = 1\)! Note that it does not matter whether we use the letter \(t\) or \(\theta\) or any other letter for the parameter.  It is just a "dummy variable". The key point for us is that we can use the trigonometric functions \(\sin\) and \(\cos\) to give a parametric representation of the equation of a circle.
